items.message: The level of Derwentwater remains high following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the lake frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site today, Tuesday (15/02/2022). Flooding of properties is not expected though the campsite itself remains closed. The forecast for today is dry but with further rainfall expected overnight into tomorrow, Wednesday (16/02/2022), we expect the level of Derwentwater to fall slowly but remain above normal. Levels are likely to rise again in response to further rain forecast, which is associated with Met Office named Storms Dudley and Eunice later on this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. The Lodore Lake Level recording gauge has developed a fault which we are seeking to rectify as soon as possible. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near Derwentwater and local watercourses, which may be flooded. This message will be updated later today, or as the situation changes

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels have receded overnight on the Upper River Derwent and Stonethwaite Beck, though the level of Derwent Water remains high following heavy rainfall over the last few days, and a Flood Warning remains in force for low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and lake frontage areas of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. No property flooding is expected. We will continue to monitor the situation closely as further rainfall is forecast for Tuesday evening (15/02/2022) and later this week, with further river response likely due to the effect of the named storms Dudley and Eunice. Our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 16/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River levels are high although now receding upstream of Windermere on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and their tributaries, following recent heavy rainfall. However, levels on Windermere and the River Leven remain high and Newby Bridge Sluices are still open. Areas most at risk include low lying areas around Ambleside, Windermere, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Today, Tuesday 15/02/2022, is forecast to be dry until evening but with more rain expected later this week, associated with named storms Dudley and Eunice, river and lake levels are expected to remain high over the next few days. We do not expect flooding to properties. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and our teams have been out checking watercourses for blockages and clearing debris screens. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Wednesday 16/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are currently rising again at the Llanymynech and Cae Howell river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. The risk of flooding of roads and farmland remains. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. 
A predicted peak at Llanymynech of 3.8 to 4.3m is expected this evening, 15/02/22, and at Cae Howel is 4.43m but rising slowly.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on 16/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise again due to heavy rainfall. 
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible again into tomorrow, Wednesday, 16/02/22. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford.
We expect river levels to rise again at all gauge locations this afternoon and overnight into tomorrow, 16/02/22. 
Predicted Peaks: Hay-on-Wye 2m-2.5m; Bredwardine 4.5m-5.0m; Belmont 4.5m-5.0m; Hereford 4m-4.5m, Mordiford 4m-4.5m. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Leek gauge. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.   
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels remain high following recent rainfall in the Yorkshire Dales. Although the level of the River Ouse has fallen below levels of concern, levels are expected to rise again overnight in response to forecast rain. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from early Wednesday morning, 16/02/2022. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads, and riverside foot and cycle paths. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and checking and operating defences as required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads or carparks near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10 pm on Tuesday, 15 February 2022 or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to begin between this evening 15/02/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. 
Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.3m to 5.8m overnight tonight, Montford 4.5m to 5.0m Thursday morning, Welshbridge 2.7m to 3.2m Thursday evening, Buildwas 3.8m to 4.3m Friday, Bridgnorth 3.5m to 4.0m Friday.
Further rain is forecast over the week and heavy rainfall is forecast for Friday overnight which may cause further rises in river levels.  We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 9am tomorrow morning 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are rising today at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall this morning Tuesday 15/02/22. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today Tuesday 15/02/22. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are expected to begin to rise again overnight at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. We expect river levels to remain high for several days.
Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.5 to 4m on Wednesday evening, 16/02/22.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Wednesday, 16/02/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: River levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 15/02/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further showers are forecast throughout today, 15/02/22, and so we expect river levels to remain high for the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  This message will be updated by 13:00 on Wednesday, 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother remains high in Fittleworth, following half a month's rainfall (35mm) on Sunday (13/02/2022). Minor flooding will continue to affect fields and gardens in Fittleworth. River levels should peak by 11:00 15/02/2022 in Fittleworth. River levels are falling in Lodsbridge near Selham, and have already fallen to near normal levels in Stedham, Midhurst, Iping, Liss and Sheet. Another 20mm of rain is possible this Tuesday afternoon (15/02/2022) into Wednesday morning (16/02/2022), which will cause the Western Rother to rise again. Minor flood impacts could return, but the river should not rise as high as in recent days. In Liss, the river could peak around 20:00 15/02/2022, and at Lodsbridge near Selham around 08:00 16/02/2022. Near Fittleworth, the river could remain higher than normal until the end of the week. Please remain prepared for further periods of the river rising and minor flood risk between Liss and Fittleworth. Take precautionary action to reduce impacts. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 19:00 on 15/02/2022.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels continue to rise steadily on the River Dee, due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Dee, in particular, low lying land and roads at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee from Tuesday morning 15/02/2022. It is likely that Townfield Lane at Farndon will get cut off as the river rises. 
The River Dee level will continue to rise throughout the week and is currently expected to peak on Saturday 19/02/2022 at approximately 8.8m. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this alert as necessary. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 16/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high and are forecast to rise further at the Lugwardine river gauge overnight tonight, because of recent heavy rainfall. 
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next few days. 
We expect river levels to remain high for several days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Wednesday, 16/02/22 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message: Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible from Tuesday afternoon 15/02/2022. Heavy rain falling today is expected to cause river levels in the Exmoor area to rise.We expect flooding to affect  low lying land and roads near Lynton and Lynmouth, Challacombe, Meethe, South Molton, Dulverton, Brushford, Winsford, Exton, Exford. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. Please take care near the areas of concern. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are rising slowly at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. 
We expect river levels to peak early tomorrow morning Wednesday, 16/02/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Wednesday, 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are peaking at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland. No flooding is currently expected at other locations.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. 
We expect river levels to remain high into tomorrow, Wednesday, 16/02/22. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hookagate river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is expected today 15/02/2022.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Church Stretton. Other locations that may be affected include Minsterley, Pontesford and Harrington. The floodplain has started to fill adjacent to the gauge on the left bank.   
  We expect river levels to remain high into tomorrow. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  by 9am tomorrow 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Newnham Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding (of property) is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Ledyche Brook and River Rea. Locations that may be affected include Cleobury Mortimer, Neen Sollars and Caynham.   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 9 am, tomorrow morning  16/02/22 or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising today at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall today Tuesday 15/02/22. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today Tuesday 15/02/22. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Onibury river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible to begin today Tuesday, 15/02/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow.
Predicted peaks:-  Leintwardine 1.0m to 1.3m overnight; Onibury 1.7m to 2.0 this afternoon; Corve 2.0m to 2.3m overnight.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to rise until later this evening, 15/02/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 9am on Wednesday 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.  We expect river levels to rise this afternoon and into this evening on 15/02/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen today at the Little Alne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening Tuesday 15/02/22 and overnight into tomorrow Wednesday 16/02/22. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 16/02/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Lower River Swale is no longer in force as river levels are now falling below levels of concern, and no further rainfall is expected overnight. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The river has now fallen below levels of concern and this Flood Alert has been removed. Rain is forecast in the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue the alert if required.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further light rainfall is forecast for today, but we do not expect the river to react. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary and are clearing debris from weed screens.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are now falling steadily this evening as rainfall has eased. No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no further rainfall for the rest of today, 14/02/22.
River levels are forecast to rise again on Tuesday afternoon in response to further rainfall so this flood alert may be issued again. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
